questions.text: A case-control study is being conducted by researchers to investigate the association between the onset of cardiovascular disease (CVD) and a high-calorie diet. Which of the following scenarios best reflects a form of Neyman bias?

options.label: A
options.text: Asking participants to recall and report their dietary habits over the past five years.

options.label: B
options.text: Excluding cases who had CVD in the past but have since died or fully recovered.

options.label: C
options.text: Including cases as patients admitted with CVD and controls as patients admitted for non-CVD causes

options.label: D
options.text: Publishing findings with a strong association, while those with inconclusive associations are unpublished.

questions.correct_answer: B. Excluding cases who had CVD in the past but have since died or fully recovered.
questions.explanation:
Neyman bias
(Option B)
  • Known as prevalence-incidence bias occurs when a study excludes individuals who have died or recovered from the disease.
  • Missing cases lead to an underestimation of the true association.

Berksonian bias

(Option C)
  • A selection bias by choosing hospitalised patients with multiple comorbidities as the study population
  • Leads to a distorted association between exposure and outcome.

Reporting bias
(Option A)
  • Information reporting is influenced by the knowledge of the desired outcome or the interest of the researchers.
  • E.g., CVD patients may attribute their condition to past dietary habits leading to high-fat consumption, while those without CVD may underreport unhealthy eating habits.

Publication bias

(Option D)
  • Studies with positive or significant results are more likely to be published than studies with negative or non-significant results.
  • This leads to an overrepresentation of studies showing a strong association between high-fat diets and CVD, potentially misleading readers.

questions.text: Which of the following statements best describes the purpose of double blinding in clinical trials

options.label: A
options.text: It fails to avoid performance bias

options.label: B
options.text: It avoids both subject and observer bias

options.label: C
options.text: Patients and the control group are unaware of their enrollment in a research trial.

options.label: D
options.text: It avoids selection bias

questions.correct_answer: B. It avoids both subject and observer bias
questions.explanation:
Blinding levels in Clinical trials

1. Single-blinded blinding
  • Participants are unaware of the intervention
  • Prevent biases that arise from knowledge of the treatment.

2. Double-blinded blinding
  • Both the researchers and participants are unaware of the intervention given (prevents observer and subject bias) (Option B and C)
  • Most common form of blinding
  • Avoids performance bias (associated with knowledge of treatment) (Option A)

3. Triple-blinded blinding
  • Researchers, participants, and analysers are unaware of the intervention.
  • The best form of blinding.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding experimental studies is false?

options.label: A
options.text: Interventional study can confirm/discard a hypothesis

options.label: B
options.text: Healthy individuals are a unit of study in randomised clinical trials

options.label: C
options.text: Cost and ethical concerns are seen in experimental studies

options.label: D
options.text: Experimental studies often include control groups to compare the effects of the intervention.

questions.correct_answer: B. Healthy individuals are a unit of study in randomised clinical trials
questions.explanation:
Experimental study

Unit of study

RCT

Diseased individuals

Field trials (e.g. Vaccine trials)

Healthy Individuals

Advantages

Disadvantages
  • Provides evidence for the direct effect of an intervention and its outcome. Hence, a disease can be confirmed using Experimental or Interventional epidemiology (Option A).
  • For example, vaccines and drug manufacturing took place after the confirmation of the COVID-19 virus.
  • Cost: Experimental studies, especially large-scale RCTs, can be expensive to conduct (Option C).

 
  • Evaluate the efficacy of new drugs, vaccines, and therapies and compare between two interventional groups.
  • Ethical concerns: Ethical considerations often pose limitations on experimental studies (Option C).
